misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Linked When One Array Is Sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also keep the `names` array aligned with the corresponding scores (or that the original indexing relationship remains valid after sorting only `scores`).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `names` and `scores` are independent arrays. `Arrays.sort(scores)` reorders only the elements in `scores`; it does not move elements in `names`. If you want to preserve the name-score pairing, you must swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or use an array/list of objects (e.g., `Student{name, score}`) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name may not match the highest score after sorting, because `names[n-1]` is still the last-entered name while `scores[n-1]` becomes the maximum score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index Correspondence Assumed After Reordering Data
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the index `n-1` refers to the same student in both arrays even after sorting, so picking `names[n-1]` and `scores[n-1]` yields the same student's data.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: After sorting only `scores`, index `n-1` refers to the largest score, but `names[n-1]` still refers to the last name entered. Index-based correspondence only holds if both arrays are reordered identically (or if no reordering occurs).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: often prints the last input name paired with the highest score from a different student.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[n - 1];
int topScore = scores[n - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays were defined and populated in a parallel fashion, any built-in operation (like Arrays.sort) performed on one array will automatically apply the same reordering or permutation to the other array to maintain the conceptual relationship between them.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory with no internal awareness of other arrays, even if they share the same length. Arrays.sort(int[]) is a utility method that only operates on the specific memory reference it is given. There is no 'linkage' mechanism in the JVM that synchronizes indices across different arrays during a mutation.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Auto-Synchronize When Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also (implicitly) keep the `names` array aligned with the corresponding scores, so that `names[n-1]` will still be the name that matches `scores[n-1]` after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. `Arrays.sort(scores)` only reorders elements inside the `scores` array; it does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate `names` array to preserve name↔score pairing. With parallel arrays, the program must swap elements in *both* arrays together whenever a swap occurs during sorting (or use a composite structure like a `Student` class/record and sort that).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the program prints the last-entered name paired with the highest score after sorting, producing an incorrect top student name whenever the highest score was not entered last.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when Arrays.sort() is called on the scores array, the names array will automatically rearrange itself to maintain the correspondence between names and scores. They assume the sorting operation somehow knows about and updates both arrays in tandem.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Arrays.sort() is a generic utility function that operates independently on a single array. It has no knowledge of parallel data structures and no mechanism to automatically update corresponding elements in other arrays. When scores[85, 92, 78] is sorted to [78, 85, 92], the names array [Alice, Bob, Charlie] remains unchanged. The index-to-value correspondence is broken: names[2]='Charlie' no longer corresponds to scores[2]=92 (which was Bob's score at index 1 before sorting).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program prints 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'. The highest score 92 is correctly identified in the sorted array, but it is now paired with the wrong name because the parallel arrays were not kept in sync.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are intended to be 'parallel' (where index i in both arrays represents the same entity), performing a built-in operation like sorting on one array will automatically apply the same reordering or permutation to the other array to keep the data synchronized.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a conceptual design choice by the programmer, not a feature of the language's execution model. The Arrays.sort() method only manipulates the specific array passed to it (scores), leaving the other array (names) in its original order. Consequently, the logical link between index i in 'names' and index i in 'scores' is destroyed.
